Available online 5 October 2025 Article Simple removal of framework aluminum from MWW type zeolites for unprecedented optimal Mo-impregnated catalysts: Systematic elucidation of coke deposition and its impact on methane dehydroaromatization Tristan James Sim a 1 Yun Ha Song a 1 Jaehee Shim a Gihoon Lee a Liangqing Li b c Young Soo Ko d Jungkyu Choi a * a Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Korea University, Seoul 02841, Republic of Koreax Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering Korea University Seoul 02841 Republic of Korea Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Korea University, Seoul 02841, Republic of Koreax b Key Laboratory of Functional Membranes and Energy Materials, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huangshan University, Huangshan 245041, Anhui, China Key Laboratory of Functional Membranes and Energy Materials School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Huangshan University Huangshan Anhui 245041 China Key Laboratory of Functional Membranes and Energy Materials, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huangshan University, Huangshan 245041, Anhui, China c Department of Chemistry, School of Chemistry and Materials, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, Anhui, China Department of Chemistry School of Chemistry and Materials University of Science and Technology of China Hefei Anhui 230026 China Department of Chemistry, School of Chemistry and Materials, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, Anhui, China d Department of Chemical Engineering, Kongju National University, Cheonan-si, Chungcheongnam-do 31080, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering Kongju National University Cheonan-si Chungcheongnam-do 31080 Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering, Kongju National University, Cheonan-si, Chungcheongnam-do 31080, Republic of Korea * Corresponding author. 1 Contributed equally to this work. In this study, we investigated Mo-impregnated H-MCM-22 catalysts (denoted Mo/M) for methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) to produce aromatics such as benzene and toluene (BT). We attempted to improve the performance of the MDA catalysts by reducing the amount of Brönsted acid sites (BAS) of the H-MCM-22 supports via hydrothermal dealumination. Among the prepared catalysts, an optimal hydrothermal treatment (HT) of H-MCM-22 supports at 400 °C, followed by Mo impregnation (denoted Mo/M_400), resulted in a reduced and optimal amount of BAS, along with a comparable Mo distribution to Mo/M. Further, Mo/M_400 enhanced BT formation rates (maximum BT formation rate of 5.23 vs. 4.73 mmolBT·g−1·h−1 for Mo/M); it appears that dealumination-induced reduction in the quantity of BAS altered their spatial interaction with active Mo species, promoting BT and naphthalene formation. Interestingly, the lifetime of intermediate C2 (ethane and ethylene) formation was also improved for Mo/M_400. Rigorous coke analyses revealed that the decreased coke content in the aromatic-selective 10-membered-ring (10-MR) pores, as well as the ability of the 12-MR pores to accommodate coke deposits over a longer reaction time, improved the stability of Mo/M_400. Nonetheless, for all catalysts, the deactivations of BAS, and subsequently, the active Mo sites were mainly ascribed to coke deposition. The overall enhancement in MDA performance by Mo/M_400 was attributed to the advantages of the optimally reduced BAS, allowing such performance to surpass those of previously reported Mo-based catalysts. Graphical Abstract Optimal hydrothermal dealumination of H-MCM-22 zeolite supports prior to Mo impregnation can enhance the catalytic activity and stability for methane dehydroaromatization by virtue of the notable effects of reduced Brönsted acid sites. Keywords Methane dehydroaromatization Dealumination MCM-22 zeolite Mo distribution Deactivation 1 Introduction The valorization of methane (CH4), a major component of natural gas, is a key strategy for providing sustainable energy and chemicals in a decarbonized future [1–5]. Therefore, the direct conversion of CH4 into value-added products such as olefins, oxygenates, and aromatics has received great attention [6–15]. These efforts are driven by the need to seek alternatives to conventional indirect CH4 utilization, such as the Fischer-Tropsch (FT) synthesis [16,17]. In the FT synthesis, CH4 is converted into syngas (i.e., CO + H2) via highly endothermic steam and/or dry reforming processes, which are energy-intensive and expensive [18–23]. In addition, direct CH4 conversion routes that can be realized on-site at remote gas fields are required to reduce long-distance transportation costs and carbon dioxide emissions [24–26]. One promising method is the non-oxidative catalytic transformation of CH4 into high-demand aromatics [27–30]. This process, more commonly known as methane dehydroaromatization (MDA), involves the dehydrogenation of CH4 over active transition metal centers (mainly molybdenum (Mo)), which are typically confined in zeolites (largely the proton form of ZSM-5; Zeolite Socony Mobil-5: MFI type zeolite), yielding C2 intermediates, such as ethane and ethylene [31]. These intermediate products are further oligomerized and cyclized by the Brönsted acid sites (BAS) present in the zeolite micropores to form aromatics (e.g., benzene, toluene, and xylene (BTX)) [11,31]. In addition to ZSM-5, MCM-22 (Mobil Composition of Matter-22: MWW type zeolite) is another type of zeolite support that is effective for MDA [32]. Specifically, MCM-22 contains two independent pore systems, namely, a smaller, two-dimensional (2D) 10-membered-ring (10-MR) sinusoidal pore system (ca. 0.41 × 0.51 nm2) and a larger, three-dimensional (3D) 12-membered-ring (12-MR) supercage pore system (ca. 0.71 × 0.71 × 1.82 nm3) interconnected by 10-MR windows (ca. 0.40 × 0.55 nm2) [33,34]. Although MCM-22 and ZSM-5, both medium-pore zeolites, possess analogous aperture sizes (ca. 0.40 × 0.55 nm2 for MCM-22 and ca. 0.51 × 0.55 nm2 for ZSM-5), Mo-impregnated MCM-22 (denoted Mo/MCM-22) outperforms its counterpart (i.e., Mo/ZSM-5) in the MDA reaction (in terms of activity and stability) by virtue of its unique topology [35–37]. First, the relatively smaller pore apertures in MCM-22 compared to ZSM-5 enhance the benzene selectivity [38], and thus, the aromatic yields [36]. In addition, the supercages in MCM-22 act as reservoirs for coke deposition, thereby exhibiting a better catalytic stability than ZSM-5 [39,40]. Another feature of Mo/MCM-22 is its ability to produce a higher yield of benzene and a lower yield of naphthalene (considered a coke precursor [41]) under similar MDA reaction conditions [35]. Finally, it is believed that Mo species tend to interact with the external silanol groups of ZSM-5, whereas such species preferentially interact with BAS within the internal zeolitic channels of MCM-22 [42]. Accordingly, the Mo species in MCM-22 become more dispersed and active toward MDA than those in ZSM-5 [42,43]. Therefore, efforts to develop high-performance Mo/MCM-22 catalysts, in addition to Mo/ZSM-5, should be prioritized. Rapid catalyst deactivation by coking is one of the main drawbacks hindering the scale-up of MDA [44–48]. One major reason is that, under typical MDA reaction conditions, formation of coke over desired products is more thermodynamically and kinetically favorable [8,27,49]. Also, although the BAS within the pore channels are significant for the aromatization of C2 intermediates, these acid sites have also been associated in facilitating carbon accumulation [50,51]. This suggests that optimization of BAS is required to favor target products while retarding coke formation [52]. Crucially, excessive amounts of BAS can catalyze unwanted reaction pathways, which lower aromatic selectivity [53,54] and promote polycondensation to polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) that eventually deposit as coke [55–57]. Similarly, the presence of large amounts of strong BAS is detrimental to the selectivity for the desired aromatic products [58,59]. Therefore, controlling the amount of acidic sites is key to determining the overall catalytic performance of MDA. Dealumination, the process of extracting framework Al atoms from zeolites, is one of the many techniques by which zeolite acidity can be modified or controlled [60]. Dealumination can be accomplished by treating zeolites with steam or silicon tetrachloride (SiCl4) vapor at high temperatures, acids (e.g., HCl or HNO3), chelating agents (e.g., ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid), or ammonium hexafluorosilicate [61–64]. Among them, steam (i.e., hydrothermal) treatment or acid treatment is economical and sustainable since they do not require expensive pressure-resistant reaction vessels or produce extremely toxic wastewater [65]. Further, the production of dealuminated zeolites can be easily scaled up because the dealumination process can operate at atmospheric pressure [66,67]. In particular, steam dealumination has been effective in improving the performance of industrially important catalytic reactions [68–72]. Moreover, the dealumination of zeolite supports (pretreatment) or metal-impregnated catalysts (post-treatment) by acid [73], steam [51,74], or a combination of both [75,76] enhances the MDA catalytic performance. We confirmed this MDA performance enhancement in our previous work on pretreating H-ZSM-5 supports with steam, improving aromatic yields (mainly benzene and toluene) at the expense of decreased coke formation [52]. Although extensive research has been devoted to the treatment of Mo-based ZSM-5 catalysts [51,73–76], to the best of our knowledge, the dealumination of Mo-based MCM-22 catalysts has remained largely unexplored, with only one reported study addressing this approach [77]. This previous work specifically involved a combination of high-temperature calcination (at 700 °C) and subsequent acid (HNO3) pretreatment of the H-MCM-22 supports before impregnation with Mo, though the specific effects of these treatments remained elusive, particularly on Mo distribution after impregnation and how this relates to catalytic performance. Nevertheless, the modified catalyst was only promising at elevated reaction temperatures (750–800 °C) exceeding the typical operating temperature (i.e., ca. 700 °C) of MDA. Consequently, the low benzene selectivity (ca. 50%) at 700 °C indicates that this catalyst still needs further improvement [77]. Thus, a study focusing on the enhancement of MDA performance by dealumination, accompanied by a comprehensive understanding of its effects, is critically needed, particularly when utilizing MCM-22-based catalysts. In this study, we employed a facile hydrothermal pretreatment for the dealumination of H-MCM-22 zeolites. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to explore and explain the effects of simple hydrothermal treatment (HT) of H-MCM-22 zeolite supports on the MDA reaction. First, H-MCM-22 supports, hydrothermally pretreated at specified temperatures, were impregnated with Mo to prepare MDA catalysts. The MDA performance was then evaluated, and the catalysts were screened to obtain three representative samples having superior, comparable, and inferior performances relative to that of the pristine H-MCM-22-based reference catalyst. The structural and textural properties of these catalysts remained intact, even after steam exposure of up to 600 °C. However, HT changed the chemical properties (i.e., amount of BAS) of the zeolite supports and, thus, those of the corresponding Mo-impregnated catalysts significantly. The MDA catalytic performance of the prepared catalysts was thoroughly assessed by considering the effects of HT on the H-MCM-22 supports and the resulting distribution of Mo species on the overall MDA performance. Rigorous analysis of coke from the spent catalysts recovered at 4-h reaction intervals from up to ca. 32 h, which has not been undertaken in previous literature, helped explain the MDA catalytic performance, particularly in determining the coke quantities within the pore systems as a function of reaction duration. In particular, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and its combination with Ar physisorption-based micropore analysis were used to identify and quantify the accumulated coke. In addition, mathematical modeling of the MDA performance was used to quantify the deactivation behavior. Finally, we evaluated the MDA performance of the optimal Mo-impregnated H-MCM-22 catalyst and compared it with those of ZSM-5- and MCM-22-supported Mo catalysts reported in the literature, revealing its superiority. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of zeolite supports MCM-22 (MWW type zeolite) and MCM-36 zeolites were obtained from a MCM-22 precursor (MCM-22(P)). MCM-22(P) was synthesized according to the methods reported previously [78,79]. First, hexamethyleneimine (HMI, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich; product number: H10401), sodium aluminate (ca. 55% Al2O3 and 45% Na2O, Sigma-Aldrich; product number: 13404), and sodium hydroxide (98%, anhydrous pellets, Sigma-Aldrich; product number: S5881) were dissolved in 50 mL of deionized (DI) water contained in a polypropylene bottle. Subsequently, fumed silica (Cab-O-Sil M-5, Cabot Corporation) was added to the solution. The final molar composition of the mixture was 100 SiO2: x Al3+: y Na+: 49.3 HMI: 4400 H2O to give a nominal Si/Al ratio of ca. 15 (x:y = 6.4:23.9). For comparison, MCM-22 precursors having nominal Si/Al ratios of ca. 30 and 50 (x:y = 3.2:24.6 and 1.9: 17.8, respectively) were also prepared using the same method. In addition, ITQ-1, which is the all-silica analog of MCM-22, was prepared using a previously reported method [80]. First, HMI and N,N,N-trimethyl-1- adamatanammonium hydroxide (TMAdaOH, 25 wt% aqueous solution, SACHEM Inc.) were added to 50 mL of DI water. Subsequently, fumed silica was added to the solution. The final molar composition of the mixture was 100 SiO2: 31 HMI: 25 TMAdaOH: 4400 H2O. The synthetic mixture prepared for the synthesis of MCM-22 or ITQ-1 was mixed using an orbital shaker (200 rpm, IST-3075, JeioTech Co., Ltd., Republic of Korea) at room temperature (RT) until the mixture became a homogenized gel. The gel was then transferred into Teflon liners, which were further moved and sealed in stainless steel autoclaves. Hydrothermal synthesis was carried out in a convection oven by rotating the autoclaves at 60 rpm at 135 °C for 11 d for MCM-22 and 150 °C for 3 d for ITQ-1. After synthesis, the autoclaves were quenched and cooled down with tap water. After adequate washing and centrifugation, the solid products were dried at 70 °C overnight prior to calcination. Dried products, which have now become MCM-22(P) or ITQ-1(P), were calcined at 550 °C for 12 h at a heating ramp of 1 °C·min−1 under 500 mL·min−1 of air to obtain the calcined MCM-22 (MCM-22(C)) or ITQ-1 (ITQ-1(C)) zeolites. In addition, MCM-36 zeolites were synthesized by swelling and pillaring MCM-22(P) (nominal Si/Al ratio of 15) based on a previously reported method [81]. A swelling suspension was prepared by mixing 5.63 g of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich; product number: H5882) and 6.10 g of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide solution (TPAOH, 40 wt% in water, Alfa Aesar; product number: 017456) in 18.0 mL of DI water. Thereafter, MCM-22(P) (1.0 g) was added to the prepared swelling suspension, followed by vigorous stirring at RT for 16 h. The resulting swollen MCM-22(P) was recovered by repeated cycles of washing and centrifugation (five cycles of 10-min centrifugation at 10,000 rpm and redispersion in DI water), and the recovered products were dried at 70 °C overnight. A portion of the resulting dried swollen powder (2.50 g) was added to 25.00 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich; product number: 86578) and stirred at 90 °C for 25 h under a nitrogen atmosphere to intercalate TEOS between the swollen MCM-22(P) layers. This mixture was then dried at 50 °C in a vacuum oven for at least 20 h to obtain the dried TEOS-intercalated MCM-22(P) powder. To further hydrolyze TEOS, the dried powder was added to DI water at a weight ratio of 100 (water-to-powder) and the pH value was adjusted to approximately 8–9 using a 1 mol·L–1 NaOH solution. The suspension was then agitated at 80 °C for 6 h. The hydrolyzed product was recovered by centrifugation and further dried at 70 °C overnight. Finally, the obtained product was calcined at 550 °C for 12 h at a heating ramp of 1 °C·min−1 under 500 mL·min−1 of air to obtain the silica-pillared MCM-36 zeolites (MCM-36(C)). To obtain proton-form zeolite supports (i.e., H-MCM-22 and H-MCM-36), MCM-22(C) and MCM-36(C) underwent ion-exchange procedures. For this purpose, MCM-22(C) or MCM-36(C) (ca. 1 g each) was added to ca. 100 g of a 1 mol·L–1 aqueous solution of NH4NO3 (98%, Sigma-Aldrich; product number: A7455) and the resulting mixture was stirred at RT for at least 12 h. The ion-exchange procedure was performed three times to ensure sufficient displacement of Na+ ions. After ion-exchange, the products were dried at 70 °C overnight and were finally calcined at 550 °C for 12 h at a heating ramp of 1 °C·min−1 under 300 mL·min−1 of air to yield H-MCM-22 or H-MCM-36 zeolite supports. These samples are denoted by M or M_p, respectively, where M indicates the MCM zeolite series (H-MCM-22 or H-MCM-36) and p in the latter represents the silica-pillared H-MCM-36 zeolite. 2.2 HT of zeolite supports HT of H-MCM-22 or H-MCM-36 zeolite supports, prepared from MCM-22(P) having a nominal Si/Al ratio of ca. 15, was conducted under an air stream (ca. 400 mL·min−1) containing 10 mol% water vapor in a tubular furnace, which comprised two heating zones at specified temperatures. First, H-MCM-22 or H-MCM-36 (ca. 1.0 g) was distributed onto two quartz boats. Upon reaching a target temperature, DI water was then introduced at a fixed rate of 2 mL·h−1 and the line connected to the furnace quartz tube was covered by a heating tape to provide 10 mol% water vapor. For convenience, the resulting HT samples are referred to as M_x_y, where x and y represent the HT temperature (°C) and duration (h), respectively. Unless otherwise mentioned, the default HT duration was 24 h and such duration (i.e., y in the sample label) is not indicated. Similarly, the hydrothermally treated H-MCM-36 is denoted by M_p_x, where x indicates the HT temperature (°C) used for the preparation of dealuminated H-MCM-36 zeolite supports and is appended to H-MCM-36 (i.e., M_p). 2.3 Preparation of Mo-impregnated catalysts An aqueous solution of ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, 99%, Sigma-Aldrich; product number: 09878) was impregnated into pristine and hydrothermally treated H-MCM-22 or H-MCM-36 supports via the incipient wetness method. The nominal loading of Mo was fixed at 6 wt% for all catalysts. For clarity, the resulting pristine H-MCM-22 supports and other HT counterparts, now impregnated with Mo, are designated hereafter as Mo/M and Mo/M_x_y, where Mo is prepended to the sample labels of the corresponding zeolite supports. Moreover, ITQ-1(C) was impregnated with 6 wt% Mo using the incipient wetness method. The Mo-impregnated ITQ-1 catalyst is referred to as Mo/ITQ-1(C). In addition, Mo-impregnated H-MCM-36 or HT derivative catalysts are labeled as Mo/M_p or Mo/M_p_x, respectively, where Mo is prepended to the sample labels of the corresponding zeolite supports. Finally, for comparison, we prepared additional catalysts with pristine H-MCM-22 supports having nominal 3 wt% and 10 wt% Mo loadings at a Si/Al ratio of ca. 15 as well as 6 wt% Mo loading at Si/Al ratios of ca. 30 and 50. For clarity, these samples are denoted by two numbers in parentheses (i.e., (n 1, n 2)), which indicate the nominal weight percent loading of Mo (n 1) and the Si/Al ratio (n 2) of the support. After Mo impregnation, all particles were dried at 70 °C overnight and further calcined at 550 °C for 12 h at a heating ramp of 1 °C·min−1 under 300 mL·min−1 of air. All characterization methods are described in Section S1 in the Supporting Information. 2.4 Catalytic tests The MDA performance of Mo-impregnated catalysts was evaluated using a fixed-bed quartz tubular reactor (length: 420 mm and inner diameter: 6.5 mm). All catalysts were pelletized, crushed, and sieved to obtain particle sizes ranging from 150 to 250 μm. The reactant gas feed consisted of CH4 and Ar (CH4/Ar = 9/1, v/v) and the amount of catalyst was fixed at ca. 0.2 g to maintain a space velocity of ca. 1500 mL·g−1·h−1 based on CH4 [82–84]. For reliable measurements, Ar served as the internal standard for the gas chromatography (GC) analysis. All reactions took place at atmospheric pressure. In a typical setup, a sieved catalyst was placed in the middle of the tube where a layer of quartz wool was inserted beforehand. Prior to charging the catalyst, zirconia-silica ceramic beads were placed into the other side of the quartz wool to diminish void space. The catalyst was thermally activated under He flow at ca. 550 °C for 1 h at a heating ramp of 2.5 °C·min−1. After maintaining this temperature, the catalyst was further heated to 700 °C at a heating ramp of 2.0 °C·min−1. Upon reaching 700 °C, the feed was switched to the reactant gas. Initial catalytic measurements were made 10 min after feeding the reactant gas to ensure full coverage of CH4 over the catalyst bed. All measurements were obtained for up to ca. 32 h at intervals of approximately 43 min using an on-line GC (6500 GC Young Lin Instrument Co., Republic of Korea) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). A capillary column (GS-GASPRO, 30 m × 0.32 mm, Agilent, USA) was connected to the FID for detecting major hydrocarbons such as methane (CH4), ethane (C2H6), ethylene (C2H4), propane (C3H8), benzene (C6H6), toluene (C7H8), and naphthalene (C10H8), while a packed column (HAYESEP DB 100-120 mesh, 30 ft × 1/8˝ × 2.0 mm, Agilent, USA) was connected to the TCD for detecting CH4 and Ar. The stainless-steel outlet line that runs from the end of the tubular reactor to the GC was maintained at 250 °C to prevent condensation and strong adsorption of aromatics (e.g., naphthalene). Methane conversion, selectivities of hydrocarbons and coke, and hydrocarbon yields were calculated based on the equations below: In this study, we also considered the hydrocarbon formation rates, which can be calculated by multiplying the feed flow rate of methane by the specific hydrocarbon yield obtained over each Mo-impregnated catalyst. For example, we evaluated the MDA performance of the tested catalysts in terms of the benzene and toluene (BT) formation rates. Building on our previous study on Mo-based ZSM-5 catalysts for MDA [52], we prescreened the Mo-impregnated catalysts, which comprised pristine MCM-22 supports (i.e., Mo/M) and those subjected to HT (i.e., Mo/M_x; x = 200, 250, 300, 350, 400, 450, 500, 600, and 700). The BT formation rates of all catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 , and their comprehensive MDA performances are displayed in Fig. S1. Beginning at an HT temperature of 200 °C (i.e., Mo/M_200), the BT formation rate increased monotonically until 400 °C (i.e., Mo/M_400), where the highest performance was observed. Meanwhile, HT temperatures higher than 400 °C decreased the performance of the respective catalysts. Based on these results, we prioritized analyzing Mo-impregnated catalysts prepared from hydrothermally treated H-MCM-22 supports at sufficiently different temperatures, which showed a superior, similar, or inferior MDA catalytic performance to that of Mo/M (i.e., the reference catalyst). Thus, with respect to Mo/M, the following catalysts were chosen based on the aforementioned criteria: (1) Mo/M_400, which not only exhibited a remarkably superior performance, but also achieved maximum BT formation rates among all tested catalysts, (2) Mo/M_500, which demonstrated an almost comparable performance, and (3) Mo/M_600, which showed a notably inferior performance though not as severe as Mo/M_700. For convenience, these four catalysts are referred to as the four representative Mo-impregnated catalysts among the prepared samples in this study. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of Mo-impregnated H-MCM-22 catalysts 3.1.1 Structural, textural, and morphological properties of Mo-impregnated H-MCM-22 catalysts The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the four representative Mo-impregnated catalysts (i.e., Mo/M and Mo/M_x; x = 400, 500, and 600) shown in Fig. 2(a) were comparable to each other and consistent with the simulated XRD pattern of the MWW type zeolite. This indicates that the zeolite crystallographic structure of the H-MCM-22 support was well-preserved up to 600 °C, as confirmed by the XRD patterns of the H-MCM-22 support series (i.e., pristine H-MCM-22 zeolite (M) and its dealuminated counterparts (M_x; x = 400, 500, and 600)) in Fig. S2. Moreover, no characteristic peaks of MoO3 species were visible in any of the XRD patterns, which could be attributed to the high dispersion of MoO3 in the zeolitic channels and/or on the external surface of the zeolite support [85]. The textural properties of the four Mo-impregnated catalysts obtained by Ar physisorption further confirmed their high zeolite framework integrity (Fig. 2(b)). All four Mo-impregnated catalysts displayed type I isotherms (Fig. 2(b)), which are typical of microporous zeolites. Notably, the isotherms shown in Fig. 2(b) were consistent with those of the H-MCM-22 support series shown in Fig. S3(a). Furthermore, the Horvath-Kawazoe (H-K) pore size distributions (Fig. 2(c)) showed that all four Mo-impregnated catalysts had two distinct zeolitic pore sizes, attributed to the MCM-22 topology: (1) 10-MR (indicated by a green arrow along with schematics of the inter- and intra-layer 10-MR channels in Fig. 2(c)) and (2) 12-MR (indicated by a light brown arrow along with a schematic of the 12-MR supercage in Fig. 2(c)) pores. In addition, no noticeable mesopores were observed in any of the four Mo-impregnated catalysts as shown by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distributions (Fig. 2(d)), indicating that HT mainly reduced the amount of micropores, if any. Accordingly, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas (S BET) of the four Mo-impregnated catalysts as well as their external and mesoporous surface areas (S ex+meso), micropore volumes (V micro), and volumes of 10-MR (V 10-MR) and 12-MR (V 12-MR) pores remained comparable up to a HT temperature of 500 °C (Table S1). However, these values slightly decreased at a treatment temperature of 600 °C, suggesting that the presence of non-framework Al entities within the pores of Mo/M_600 reduced Ar adsorption [86]. This was consistent with the lower differential pore volumes of both the hydrothermally treated support (M_600 in Figs. S3(a)-(b) and Table S1) and the corresponding Mo-impregnated catalyst (Mo/M_600 in Figs. 2(b), (c) and Table S1) [87]. Regarding surface morphology, the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of Mo/M_x (x = 400, 500, and 600) (Figs. S4(b)–(d)) revealed no significant differences with respect to Mo/M (Fig. S4(a)). Scanning electron microscopy-energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDX) analysis (Table S2) also showed that the Mo contents and Si/Al ratios of the four catalysts were comparable, suggesting minor differences in their physical properties. 3.1.2 Acidic properties of the H-MCM-22 support series and their Mo-impregnated catalysts The acid amounts of the H-MCM-22 support series and their Mo-impregnated catalysts obtained from ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) (Figs. 3(a) , (b) and S5(a), (b)) and pyridine (Py)-adsorption Fourier transform-infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy (Figs. 3(c), (d)) analyses are shown in Figs. S6(a), (b) (dealuminated support-based results (before and after Mo impregnation) relative to the pristine MCM-22-based counterparts (i.e., M and Mo/M)) and summarized in Table 1 . Although some differences in the acid amounts obtained from both NH3-TPD and Py-adsorption FT-IR were expected from the use of different probe molecules, the trends in the relative BAS amounts were in good agreement (Figs. S6(a), (b)) [88]. According to the HT-based dealumination effect [89-91], the amount of total BAS in the hydrothermally treated H-MCM-22 supports (i.e., M_x; x = 400, 500, and 600), estimated from both NH3-TPD (Fig. 3(a)) and Py-adsorption FT-IR (Fig. 3(c)) measurements, decreased monotonically relative to the pristine H-MCM-22 support (M). In addition, the acid strengths in M_x (x = 400, 500, and 600) decreased monotonically compared to that of M (dashed line in Fig. 3(a)). Specifically, the desorption temperatures of the strong acid sites in M centered at ca. 390 °C reduced to ca. 379, 363, and 332 °C for M_x (x = 400, 500, and 600), respectively (Figs. 3(a) and S5(a)), indicating that HT affected both the total amount of medium-strength (M) and strong (S) BAS (BASM+S) and the acid strength [76]. With respect to the four Mo-impregnated catalysts, the NH3-TPD profiles (Fig. 3(b)) demonstrated that the amount of total BASM+S in Mo/M_x (x = 400, 500, and 600) decreased relative to Mo/M. This could be attributed to the decrease in the amount of BAS, which was proportional to the degree of dealumination of the corresponding zeolite support. This was also the case with the Py-adsorption FT-IR measurements (Fig. 3(d)) except for Mo/M_400, which had a slightly higher total BAS amount (436.5 vs. 412.9 μmol·g−1 of Mo/M as shown in Table 1). The decrease in BAS after the dealumination of M by HT at 400 °C (i.e., M_400) was likely compensated for and further exceeded by the increase in BAS in Mo/M_400 (i.e., after Mo impregnation). This might be caused by weakly acidic bridging Mo−O(H)−Si sites formed upon outgassing (i.e., pretreating under vacuum before Py adsorption) a Mo-containing zeolite [92]. However, considering that the outgassing procedure was conducted for all four Mo-impregnated catalysts, this increase in BAS could come from additional interactions between Mo and some species arising from M_400 (possibly non-framework Al species arising from dealumination) [93–95]. Nevertheless, this phenomenon was not detected by NH3-TPD analysis, for which we considered the medium-strength and strong BAS [52,85]. As described in the characterization methods (see Section S1), the NH3-TPD technique has some intrinsic limitations preventing reliable quantification, mainly the difficulty in decoupling the weak acid site regions (i.e., physisorbed NH3 and Si−OH groups could also contribute to the NH3-TPD peaks at temperatures lower than 200 °C) [96,97]. Therefore, complementary NH3-TPD and Py-adsorption FT-IR analyses, as done in this study, are desirable for proper evaluation of acidic properties [98]. Notably, the additional generation of foreign BAS was more prominent when comparing the amounts of total BAS before and after Mo impregnation (i.e., the cases with Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600). We expected that after Mo impregnation, the amount of total BAS in the H-MCM-22 support series should decrease because of Mo migration into the pores and replacement of BAS at exchange sites, thereby anchoring the Mo species necessary for MDA [99–101]. However, as shown in Table 1, Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600 contained higher amounts of total BAS than the corresponding supports (M_500 and M_600), though this was not the case for Mo/M and Mo/M_400 with the corresponding supports (M and M_400). We surmise that in addition to the aforementioned outgassing procedure, the interactions of Mo with non-framework Al species generated from HT at high temperatures likely contributed to the formation of these additional acidic sites [93–95], exceeding the amount of BAS in the respective support. Indeed, the formation of BAS after Mo loading has been reported for alumina and silica-alumina supports, which could be explained, among other possible reasons, by Mo strongly bound to Al in a monodentate manner [102–104]. Nevertheless, the absence of a noticeable increase in BAS after Mo impregnation for Mo/M and Mo/M_400 relative to M and M_400 could be attributed to the reduction of sufficient amounts of BAS within the zeolite supports owing to Mo anchoring. In turn, the various changes in the amounts of BAS before and after Mo impregnation suggest differences in the Mo distributions in the Mo-impregnated catalysts, especially in the case of Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600. On the other hand, the Lewis acid sites, which are generally regarded as inconsequential to MDA [105,106], decreased after Mo impregnation (Table 1), further indicating the interaction of Mo with the respective zeolite support [107,108]. 3.1.3 Nuclear magnetic resonance analysis of the H-MCM-22 support series and their Mo-impregnated catalysts Considering that BAS are related to the framework Al, we also conducted 27Al magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) spectroscopy to analyze the states of the Al species in the H-MCM-22 support series (i.e., M and M_x; x = 400, 500, and 600). The 27Al MAS NMR spectrum of the pristine H-MCM-22 support (M) (Fig. 4(a) ) displayed distinguishable peaks at ca. 60, 56, 50, and 0 ppm, which was in good agreement with previous studies [109,110]. As reported, the first three peaks, with the main peak at ca. 56 ppm and its shoulders at ca. 60 and 50 ppm, are associated with the tetrahedrally coordinated framework Al. Despite the uncertainty in the literature regarding the peak assignments, the peaks at ca. 56 and 60 ppm are said to belong to T-sites situated in sinusoidal channels, supercages, or surface pockets, whereas the peak at ca. 50 ppm is said to particularly contribute to framework Al located externally or in supercages [111,112]. In addition, the last peak at ca. 0 ppm corresponds to octahedrally coordinated extra-framework Al. With the increase in HT temperature, the peaks, attributed to the tetrahedrally coordinated framework Al, decreased monotonically, indicating that HT removed Al from the framework of the zeolite supports [89–91]. However, the reduced peak intensities corresponding to tetrahedrally coordinated framework Al in M_x (x = 400, 500, and 600) were not compensated by those arising from new octahedrally coordinated extra-framework Al. This indicates the presence of NMR-invisible Al species, which are often found in steamed zeolites [88,113]. In addition, HT might change the coordination geometry of Al atoms, causing a distorted tetrahedral or octahedral environment [110]. Consequently, the quadrupole interactions of the Al atoms increased, and the MAS NMR signals broadened, as was the case with M_x (x = 400, 500, and 600) (Fig. 4(a)). In addition, the broad resonance at ca. 30 ppm associated with the penta-coordinated non-framework Al gradually increased in intensity with increasing HT temperature [110]. As expected from the close relationship between the BAS and the framework Al, the 27Al MAS NMR results of M_x (x = 400, 500, and 600), which showed a reduction in the tetrahedrally coordinated framework Al, followed a decreasing trend in the BAS with increasing HT temperature (Figs. 3(a) and (c) and Table 1). The states of the Al species present in the four Mo-impregnated catalysts were also analyzed (Fig. 4(b)). After Mo impregnation (i.e., Mo/M), the intensity of the main peak at ca. 56 ppm decreased and its lineshape became smoother compared to that of M. These suggest that there was a strong interaction between the Mo species and H-MCM-22 framework, likely caused by the proximity of the cationic Mo-oxo complexes that replaced the protons [42,114]. Similar changes were observed in the 27Al MAS NMR spectra of Mo/M_x (x = 400, 500, and 600) compared to those of the corresponding bare supports (i.e., M_x; x = 400, 500, and 600). Moreover, the introduction of Mo resulted in a new peak at ca. 14 ppm in all 27Al MAS NMR spectra (Fig. 4(b)). This new peak was ascribable to the hydrated form of a MDA-inactive aluminum molybdate (Al2(MoO4)3) phase, which could be found in Mo-impregnated catalysts with high Mo loadings (> 2 wt%) [42,115,116]. Intriguingly, the spectrum of Mo/M_400 showed a pronounced main peak (ca. 56 ppm) among the four catalysts. Although it is difficult to explain this based on the one-dimensional 27Al MAS NMR spectrum, it might result from the presence of metal-distorted tetrahedral Al species caused by Mo-zeolite guest-host interactions that intensified the main peak [117]. Further insights into the structures of the H-MCM-22 support series and their Mo-impregnated catalysts were obtained using 29Si MAS NMR spectroscopy (Figs. S7(a), (b)) and are discussed in Section S2.1. 3.2 MDA catalytic performance of Mo-impregnated H-MCM-22 catalysts All four Mo-impregnated catalysts (i.e., Mo/M and Mo/M_x; x = 400, 500, and 600) displayed similar time-dependent BT formation trends over a ca. 32-h time-on-stream (TOS) (Fig. 5(a) ), comprising three main stages (activation, induction, and deactivation) [56]. The activation stage is the period where little to no BT products were initially detected because Mo oxides are still being carburized by the CH4 feed into active Mo carbides (TOS of ca. 0.2 h) [49,56]. After adequate activation, BT products were observed at a TOS of ca. 0.9 h, representing an induction period. Subsequently, the four catalysts achieved maximum BT formation rates, albeit at different TOS (ca. 2.3, 3.8, 2.2, and 1.6 h for Mo/M, Mo/M_400, Mo/M_500, and Mo/M_600, respectively). Finally, the BT formation rates decreased, apparently because of inevitable deactivation. As noted in Section 2.4, Mo/M_400 showed the best MDA performance, achieving higher BT formation rates than Mo/M until complete catalyst deactivation (Fig. 5(a)). In this work, HT for 24 h showed the best catalytic performance for Mo/M_400 in comparison with other HT durations of 12, 36, and 48 h (Fig. S8). Higher HT temperatures (500 and 600 °C), however, did not further improve the BT formation rates and instead hastened deactivation (Fig. 5(a)). Further, the order of increase in BT formation rates (i.e., Mo/M_400 > Mo/M > Mo/M_500 > Mo/M_600) was nearly consistent with the order of increase in the naphthalene formation rates over the entire TOS (inset in Fig. 5(a)), as well as CH4 conversions mainly between the TOS of ca. 4–20 h (Fig. 5(b)). With respect to CH4 conversions, such an observation allowed us to speculate that the spatial interactions of Mo with the BAS within the zeolite supports were different for each catalyst [106,118]. Because CH4 activation on active Mo sites generally produces C2 hydrocarbons [56,119], the C2 formation rates can provide insights into the Mo distribution in each catalyst. Fig. 6 suggests that the differences in the BT formation rates among the four Mo-impregnated catalysts were related to the corresponding C2 formation rates and, possibly, their Mo distributions. All profiles of the C2 formation rates exhibited two stages; the first (fitted slopes indicated by dashed lines in Fig. 6) involved a steady increase in C2 production, and the second involved a decrease (shaded orange in Fig. 6). Notably, the C2 formation rates of Mo/M_400, whose BT formation rates were the highest, steadily increased before decreasing at a TOS of ca. 25.3 h, which was found to be the longest TOS compared to its counterparts (TOS of ca. 21.7 h for Mo/M, ca. 17.4 h for Mo/M_500, and ca. 13.1 h for Mo/M_600). Intriguingly, the initial point of decrease could signify the inflection point of each BT formation rate profile, suggesting that the decrease in the C2 formation rates was correlated with the inability of the Mo-impregnated catalysts to further produce considerable amounts of BT (i.e., target product). This is because at this point, the deactivation of the Mo species had begun. Moreover, considering that the slopes of C2 formation rates of Mo/M and Mo/M_400 in the first stage were similar (Figs. 6(a), (b)), it seems that the BT molecules from Mo/M_400 overcame successive reaction pathways that preferentially formed coke along their diffusion path because the BAS within the catalyst would not be too close to each other (i.e., as a result of the reduced BAS in M_400), explaining the better catalytic activity of Mo/M_400 [120,121]. The C2 formation rates during the first stage for Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600 (dashed lines in Fig. 6(c)-(d)) were higher than those of Mo/M and Mo/M_400, indicating that these catalysts were more C2-selective (without further aromatic formation) than Mo/M and Mo/M_400 (Fig. S9). However, the catalyst lifetime did not improve for Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600. The 27Al MAS NMR spectra of the H-MCM-22 support series (Fig. 4(a)) indicated that HT caused reductions in framework Al (hence, the BAS) and gave rise to non-framework Al species, thereby influencing and decreasing the amount of sites for anchoring Mo species. This could be reflected by the aforementioned generation of foreign BAS after Mo impregnation, as observed for Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600. However, understanding the exact roles of such non-framework Al species in determining the final Mo distribution and, in general, the MDA reaction requires complex in-situ investigations. Nevertheless, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results of Mo/M_x (x = 400, 500, and 600) (Fig. 7(a) ) confirmed that the chemical state of Mo was comparable to that of Mo/M, regardless of the applied HT temperature. Therefore, only the Mo distribution was affected by HT. To understand the Mo distribution further, an H2-temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) analysis was conducted (Figs. 7(b) and S10). Three reduction regions were identified; region I (ca. 350–450 °C), region II (ca. 450–700 °C), and region III (ca. 700–900 °C) [122–124]. Region I was attributed to the partial reduction of amorphous polymeric molybdate species, whereas regions II and III corresponded to the reduction of octahedrally coordinated MoO3 to MoO2 (i.e., Mo6+ → Mo4+) and further reduction of Mo4+ species to metal Mo (i.e., Mo4+ → Mo0), respectively. The most conspicuous difference was observed in region II; Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600 showed high concentrations of MoO3, indicating that it was highly dispersed on the external surface. Furthermore, the H2-TPR profile of Mo/M_600 was similar to that of Mo/ITQ-1(C), which could contain Mo species predominantly on its external surface because of the lack of BAS inside ITQ-1(C) for anchoring the Mo species. Given that the Mo species located on the external surface are less active than those in the zeolite pores [125], the poor catalytic performance of Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600 (Figs. 5(a), (b)) could be attributed to the high proportion of MoO3 on the external surface. This is supportive to the fact that HTs at 500 and 600 °C significantly reduced framework Al and, concomitantly, the amount of BAS within the zeolite supports, which further affected the distribution and activity of the Mo species significantly. This can be reflected in the differences in the TOS at which Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600 achieved their maximum BT formation rates, as noted earlier. However, the differences in MDA performance could not be easily explained from the Mo distributions in Mo/M and Mo/M_400 because their H2-TPR profiles were comparable. To understand the performance of Mo/M and Mo/M_400 at early TOS (i.e., where differences in BT formation rates began to be significant), we focused on the CH4 conversions (Fig. 5(b)) particularly at the TOS of ca. 4.5–8.1 h, a period during which the H-MCM-22-supported Mo catalysts (1) are fully carburized to produce C2 hydrocarbons and (2) are sufficiently active to form aromatics from C2 hydrocarbons [126]. In addition, in this TOS range, a major contribution to coke formation would come from detectable aromatics, such as BT and naphthalene [127]. Thus, we examined the total amount of coke in Mo/M and Mo/M_400, estimated from the TGA measurements (detailed results and discussion are provided later in the next section) after a ca. 8-h reaction. Interestingly, after ca. 8 h of reaction, the corresponding spent Mo/M and Mo/M_400 catalysts had comparable total amounts of coke (ca. 0.098 and 0.104 gcoke·g−1, respectively). Initially, we anticipated that the increase in the formation rates of BT and naphthalene (which was the case for Mo/M_400) was due to the accompanying decrease in coke formation. This was the primary effect of HT exhibited by the optimal H-ZSM-5-supported Mo catalyst in our previous work [52]. However, this was not necessarily the case for Mo/M_400, given that a comparable total amount of coke was generated relative to Mo/M. Thus, we inferred that routes for coke formation from BT (Fig. 5(a)) and naphthalene (inset in Fig. 5(a)) at TOS of ca. 4.5–8.1 h were complex in H-MCM-22-supported Mo catalysts (apparently because of the unique support topology) [126] and were each different for Mo/M and Mo/M_400. In the case of ZSM-5-supported Mo catalysts, it was reported that the spatial interaction of active Mo species with BAS was significant for MDA based on sophisticated solid-state NMR techniques [106,118]. Accordingly, we hypothesized that the decreased BAS in Mo/M_400 resulting from dealumination altered their interaction with Mo species to favor BT and naphthalene formation. On the other hand, the amounts of coke in Mo/M and Mo/M_400 after ca. 8 h of reaction were comparable, seemingly because of the decreased but still sufficient amounts of BAS in Mo/M_400 (Fig. S6(b) and Table 1). Considering the similarities in the Mo distributions in Mo/M and Mo/M_400, the different distributions of BAS between these catalysts potentially resulted in distinct catalytic routes for this pair of catalysts toward products. Nevertheless, this cannot entirely explain why Mo/M_400 was more stable than Mo/M for the rest of the TOS (as reflected by the different trends in the BT formation rates in Fig. 5(a)). Therefore, to understand the catalytic stability, a more rigorous coke analysis was conducted in the next section. 3.3 Coke and deactivation analyses of Mo-impregnated H-MCM-22 catalysts In this study, we adopted a dealumination strategy to improve both catalytic activity and stability to favor the production of BT over coke. To understand coke formation and stability, we analyzed the coke deposited on the four spent Mo-impregnated catalysts (i.e., Mo/M and Mo/M_x; x = 400, 500, and 600) recovered at 4-h intervals after reaction for up to ca. 32 h (i.e., ca. 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24, 28, and 32 h). We chose a maximum time of ca. 32 h because even the highest-performing catalyst (Mo/M_400) was completely deactivated by this time (i.e., BT formation rate became almost nil) as shown in Fig. 5(a). For rigorous analyses, we investigated coke formation using two approaches: (1) TGA alone and (2) combined TG and Ar physisorption analyses. From the former, we identified the types of coke present in the spent catalysts. Based on the differential weight percentage profiles of the spent catalysts recovered after ca. 32 h of reaction (Fig. S11), two main weight losses were observed; one (pronounced) at a lower temperature and the other at a higher temperature, which were consistent with the coke combustion temperatures of a spent Mo/H-MCM-22 catalyst with 6 wt% Mo [128]. The lower-temperature weight loss (< 500 °C) was ascribable to graphite-like coke (also known as soft coke), primarily originating from the cracking of C2 intermediates [55,129], whereas the higher-temperature weight loss (> 500 °C) resulted from aromatic-like coke (also known as hard coke), mainly resulting from the polycondensation of aromatics [114,130]. However, considering that all spent catalysts were completely deactivated after ca. 32 h, it would be more appropriate to track and quantify the degree of coke formation as a function of TOS and, thus, understand the time-dependent deactivation behavior. Therefore, as previously mentioned, we performed MDA reactions for different reaction durations (i.e., ca. 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24, 28, and 32 h) and the corresponding recovered (spent) catalysts were used for TGA measurements. Notably, the BT yields of all Mo-impregnated catalysts for the aforementioned TOS were comparable to the original BT yields of the 32-h reactions, demonstrating the high reproducibility of the current MDA catalytic performance in this study (Fig. S12). Thus, a reliable discussion of the deactivation behaviors as a function of reaction duration was achieved for the prepared catalysts in this study. Accordingly, TGA measurements of the spent catalysts were reasonable for gaining insights into coke formation during the MDA reaction. Fig. 8(a) shows the accumulated amounts of soft and hard coke, estimated from the differential weight profiles in Fig. S13, plotted against the specified reaction duration. First, we noticed that the accumulated amount of soft coke for all the spent Mo-impregnated catalysts steadily increased over the entire reaction duration (ca. 32 h). This phenomenon can be explained by examining the C2 formation rates in Fig. 6. Notably, for all four Mo-impregnated catalysts, the C2 formation rates kept increasing past the maximum BT formation rates (i.e., decreasing BT formation). Furthermore, C2 intermediates are still being produced after the point of decline (shaded orange in Fig. 6) even if the BT formation rates were almost trivial (relative to the maximum). From these observations, it is highly plausible that the continuous deposition of soft coke can be attributed to the cracking of C2 hydrocarbons [55,126]. Linear fitting enabled the calculation of the accumulation rates of soft coke, which were similar (average of ca. 3.59 mgcoke·g−1·h−1) for all four Mo-impregnated catalysts. Meanwhile, Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600 showed suppressed hard coke formation (Figs. 8(a) and S14(a)), apparently because of the extensive removal of BAS than in Mo/M and Mo/M_400 (Table 1). In contrast to that of soft coke, the accumulated amounts of hard coke for all four Mo-impregnated catalysts did not increase further with time (i.e., asymptotic after ca. 12 h). Given that hard coke can be formed by the polycondensation of aromatics over the BAS within the zeolite pores, leading to their blockage [44], the inhibition of hard coke formation was due to the inaccessibility of the BAS to CH4, C2 intermediates, or aromatics as a result of coke deposition. Despite the complete deactivation of the four catalysts, NH3-TPD analysis of the spent Mo-impregnated catalysts reacted for ca. 32 h revealed that the accessible BAS (i.e., BASM+S) within the zeolite pores were still present in considerable amounts (Fig. S15). Considering the smaller kinetic diameter of NH3 (0.26 nm [131]) compared to CH4 (0.38 nm [132]), C2 intermediates (ethane: 0.44 nm [133]; ethylene: 0.42 nm [133]), and aromatics (benzene: 0.58 nm [134]; toluene: 0.59 nm [135]; naphthalene: 0.62 nm [136]), these larger MDA-related molecules are unlikely to contribute significantly to hard coke formation at later stages of the reaction due to the restricted access to BAS. Therefore, coke deposition within the zeolite pores was one of the primary causes of the deactivation of H-MCM-22-supported Mo-based catalysts. In addition to the nature of the coke formed in the four spent Mo-impregnated catalysts, we also examined the amounts of coke formed internally and externally through the combined TG and Ar physisorption analyses because the TGA measurements alone could not distinguish the location of coke depositions. For this, as described in the characterization methods (see Section S1), we first quantified the amount of internal coke formed within the zeolitic pores after different reaction times. To do this, the differences between the fresh and spent V 10-MR and V 12-MR values obtained from deconvoluted H-K pore size distributions (Fig. S16) were multiplied by the assumed coke densities (d 1 = 1.22 g·cm−3 or d 2 = 1.50 g·cm−3). Here, d 1 is the density representative of polyaromatic coke [137,138], whereas d 2 is ascribed to the density of zeolite-templated carbon, which could be graphite-like in nature (i.e., soft) [139–142] and likely resembles carbonaceous deposits formed during MDA at longer TOS [143]. For clarity, we set the densities of coke at reaction durations before and after ca. 12 h equal to d 1 and d 2, respectively, because the polyaromatic hard coke fractions for almost all Mo-impregnated catalysts became asymptotic after approximately 12 h, but the graphite-like soft coke fractions continued to increase and dominate (Fig. 8(a)). Finally, the amount of external coke was simply obtained by subtracting the amount of internal coke from that of the total coke determined from the TGA measurements. The resulting accumulated amounts of internal and external coke are plotted against the specified reaction duration in Fig. 8(b). We found that the trends in the external coke deposition in Mo/M and Mo/M_400, which increased linearly, were comparable. This suggests that the distribution of Mo on the surface of these catalysts, based on H2-TPR analysis, was nearly identical (Fig. 7(b)) and, thus, the accumulated amounts of external coke were comparable. Meanwhile, different external coke deposition behaviors were observed for Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600, in which the suppression of external coke was observed at longer reaction durations (ca. 16–24 h). This could be attributed to the difference in the Mo distribution (i.e., the aforementioned higher concentration of MoO3 on the external surface) for Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600 (Fig. 7(b)). In addition, the accumulated amounts of internal coke in Mo/M and Mo/M_400 were comparable, whereas much lower amounts of internal coke relative to those of external coke were found in Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600 (Fig. S14(b)). The reduced amount of internal coke could be due to the drastically decreased amounts of BAS, which could anchor active Mo sites within the zeolite pores and promote BT formation, resulting in less internal coke deposition (Fig. S14(b)). To understand the improved stability of Mo/M_400 over Mo/M, we compared the accumulated amounts of coke in the 12-MR pores to those in the 10-MR pores, because the former are suitable reservoirs for coke deposition [40,144]. In fact, the facilitation of naphthalene and coke formation is likely ascribed to the lack of spatial constraint within the 12-MR pores (ca. 0.71 nm) [145]. This is evidenced by other industrially relevant reactions over H-MCM-22 catalysts, where coke predominantly forms within the 12-MR supercages [144,146,147]. For supplementary insights, we investigated Mo-impregnated H-MCM-36, a catalyst with a pillared zeolite support having fewer 12-MR pores in contrast to H-MCM-22 (Fig. S17), as well as Mo-impregnated H-ZSM-5, a catalyst having no 12-MR pores. Comparing the MDA performance of these catalysts (Fig. S18) with Mo/M and Mo/M_400 emphasized the advantage of H-MCM-22’s unique pore system (see Section S2.2). In particular, although the coke behavior in H-ZSM-5 from our previous study [52] was rather straightforward, the distinctive micropore structures of H-MCM-22 allowed for the improved catalyst stability, where 12-MR pores are specifically identified as coke reservoirs. The ratios of the amount of coke in the 12-MR pores to that in the 10-MR pores, as well as their absolute amounts, are shown in Figs. 8(c) and (d1), respectively. Based on Fig. 8(c), the higher coke ratios for Mo/M_400 at later reaction times suggest that the ability of 12-MR pores to accommodate coke was enhanced because of the decreased amounts of coke in 10-MR pores (Fig. 8(d1)) compared to Mo/M. Because MDA would be more selective to aromatics in the shape-selective 10-MR pores of MCM-22 rather than in the 12-MR pores [148,149], lower amounts of coke in the 10-MR pores could then allow for increased formation of aromatics. Thus, the improved performance of Mo/M_400 could be associated with the decreased amount of BAS associated with the 10-MR pores facilitating coke formation, though there remained the possibility of a slight decrease in BAS associated with the 12-MR pores as well. Nonetheless, the decrease is more prominent for the harsher HT cases (i.e., Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600), wherein less accumulated coke was formed in their 12-MR pores, demonstrating the role of HT in severely reducing the framework Al within these pore systems. This suggests the possibility of the slight removal of BAS associated with the 12-MR pores of Mo/M_400. A probe reaction such as toluene disproportionation could better reveal changes in the distribution of BAS within the 12-MR pores [150], but it can only be reliably used for bare H-MCM-22. For Mo-impregnated H-MCM-22, this approach cannot be considered since Mo species can act as active sites in toluene disproportionation [151,152]. We then looked into naphthalene formation to, at least, shed light on the distribution of BAS associated with the 12-MR pores. This is valid given the affinity of naphthalene to form within these pores [153]. For better understanding, we compared the naphthalene formation rates (Fig. S19) of Mo/M and Mo/M_400 to those of reference and optimal H-ZSM-5-supported Mo catalysts (denoted Mo/Z and Mo/Z_400, respectively, in Fig. S19) having no 12-MR pores from our previous work [52]. We focused on a reaction period until ca. 12 h given that accumulation of polyaromatic hard coke began to be asymptotic at this time (Fig. 8(a)). Based on Fig. S19, it was apparent that naphthalene formation was lesser in H-MCM-22-based catalysts than in H-ZSM-5-based ones, regardless of HT. This is a distinct feature of H-MCM-22-based catalysts, as mentioned in the Introduction and is attributed to the difference in strong acid strengths between H-MCM-22 and H-ZSM-5, with the former having a lower one and thus, lower naphthalene formation [35]. Nevertheless, upon comparison of Mo/M_400 and Mo/Z_400, a slight increase in naphthalene formation (beginning at ca. 4 h of reaction) was observed from the former relative to Mo/M. Meanwhile, naphthalene formation was similar for both Mo/Z and Mo/Z_400. Interestingly, coke formation is comparable for Mo/M and Mo/M_400, while that of Mo/Z_400 decreased relative to Mo/Z, as noted in Section 3.2. Thus, we speculate that due to the absence of a 12-MR supercage system in H-ZSM-5, similar amounts of naphthalene were still produced regardless of HT. Although it is evident that naphthalene formation increased because of the improved BT formation in Mo/M_400 (Fig. 5(a)), as with BT molecules, naphthalene molecules may have also overcome coke-selective pathways along their diffusion path given that the slightly reduced BAS (by virtue of HT) associated with the 12-MR pores would be less proximate to each other. We further investigated the superior performance of Mo/M_400 relative to the other Mo-impregnated catalysts (especially Mo/M) by investigating the relationships, if any, between the coke deposition behaviors in the 10- and 12-MR pores and the formation rates of BT and C2. For clarity, the accumulated amounts of coke in the 10- and 12-MR pores are plotted as a function of reaction time (Fig. 8(d1)) and the BT and C2 formation rates are plotted as a function of TOS (Fig. 8(d2)). Again, coke deposition was more favorable in the 12-MR pores, especially for Mo/M and Mo/M_400, as expected from previous studies [40,154,155]. Indeed, in MCM-22 zeolite-supported Mo-based catalysts, higher coke quantities were deposited in the 12-MR pores than in the 10-MR pores. Concerning the coke deposition behavior of the 12-MR pores in Mo/M and Mo/M_400, we found that the 12-MR pores of the latter could accommodate coke deposits for a longer reaction time (ca. 24 h) without severely affecting the BT formation rates (i.e., with linearly decreasing formation rates; indicated by orange dashed lines in Fig. 8(d2)), compared to the 12-MR pores of the former (ca. 20 h) before the coke accumulated at a slower rate (as indicated by the transition of orange-to-red dashed lines in Fig. 8(d1)). The inflection points in the BT formation rate profiles seemingly reflected the point of trend change in coke deposition in the 12-MR pores in Mo/M and Mo/M_400 (as indicated by the downward red arrow from Fig. 8(d1) to (d2)). However, this was not clearly observed in Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600, possibly because of the extensive removal of the framework Al from the 12-MR pores. Meanwhile, the trend changes in the coke deposition behavior in the 10-MR pores for all four spent catalysts (as indicated by the transition of gray-to-black dashed lines in Fig. 8(d1)) seemed to correspond to the C2 formation rate behaviors (as indicated by the upward black arrow from Figs. 8(d2) to (d1)). Considering that BT molecules are likely selectively produced from C2 hydrocarbons in the 10-MR pores rather than in the non-selective 12-MR pores, as established previously, the C2 formation rates will be more dependent on the 10-MR pores. Additionally, the relationship between the coke amounts and formation rates shown in Figs. 8(d1), (d2) suggests that the coke deposition rate within the 10-MR pores was sufficiently slow (indicated by the gray dashed line in Fig. 8(d1)) to allow C2 hydrocarbons to form steadily; otherwise, an inferior catalytic performance would be obtained. In addition, we found that when the trend of C2 formation rate dramatically decreased (as indicated by the transition of gray-to-black dashed lines in Fig. 8(d2)), the coke formation in the 10-MR pores further increased (as indicated by the gray-to-black dashed lines in Fig. 8(d1)). This indicates that the active Mo sites became inaccessible to CH4 because of the formed coke and, accordingly, C2 formation was prohibited and retarded considerably. Finally, the prolonged TOS (here, ca. 32 h vs. ca. 12 h in our previous study [52]) for MDA allowed us to identify the trend changes in BT and C2 formation rates with the corresponding changes in coke formation in the 10- and 12-MR pores. Essentially, the improved catalytic performance of Mo/M_400 relative to Mo/M, coupled with its stability in the MDA reaction, likely originated from the decreased amounts of coke in its 10-MR pores as well as the ability of its 12-MR pores to accommodate coke deposits at a longer reaction time. This could be linked to the appropriate amount and strength of BAS throughout the reaction duration in Mo/M_400, allowing for increased production and desorption of aromatics before reaching final coke formation. Based on our analysis in Section 3.2 and in this section, we proposed a possible reaction scheme for the overall MDA reaction of all four representative Mo-impregnated catalysts (Scheme 1 ). The reaction began with the dehydrogenation of CH4 over active Mo species to produce C2 intermediates. These C2 intermediates were simultaneously and effectively converted into aromatic compounds (mainly BT) within the zeolite pores. However, BT and naphthalene could further polymerize through the BAS, eventually depositing as hard coke, which, in turn, could block micropores and access to the BAS. This could be one of the primary causes of catalyst deactivation [49,114]. Moreover, although the BT and naphthalene formation rates decreased over time, the C2 formation rates steadily increased until they suddenly decreased (Fig. 6). We hypothesized that at this transition point, the active Mo species started to deactivate as well. Considering that the total accessible zeolitic pore volumes continued to decrease over reaction time (Fig. S20), along with an increase in the accumulated soft coke (Fig. 8(a)), we concluded that the deactivation of the active Mo species was closely related to the continuous deposition of soft coke. Since the amount of accessible BAS would be too low during the reaction period after passing through such a transition point to be responsible for hard coke deposition, it was likely that the cracking of C2 hydrocarbons into soft coke, as explained earlier, constituted another pathway for catalyst deactivation at prolonged reaction times [55,126]. In terms of coke location, it may be interpreted that both internal and external coke could account for deactivation based on Fig. 8(b). However, the relationships drawn between internal coke (i.e., coke in the 10- and 12-MR pores) and the BT and C2 formation rates (Figs. 8(d1), (d2)) indicated that internal coke determined overall catalyst deactivation. This is a plausible explanation, as the 2D pore structure of H-MCM-22 makes it unlikely for external coke to hinder diffusion of aromatic products and thereby induce deactivation. To quantify the apparent effects of HT on the overall performances of the Mo-impregnated catalysts, we estimated the rate constants (k) and deactivation coefficients (a) from the BT yields of the four representative catalysts by fitting the following equation [156] to the experimental data: (1) X = ( exp ( k τ 0 ) - 1 ) exp ( - k a t ) 1 + ( exp ( k τ 0 ) - 1 ) exp ( - k a t ) where X is the reactant conversion, k () is the rate constant, a () is the deactivation coefficient, τ 0 () is the contact time, and t (h) is the reaction time. This equation assumes that (1) the reaction follows a first-order reaction, and (2) the deactivation (i.e., decreased) rate is proportional to the decreased number of active sites rather than the decrease in their intrinsic activities [156,157]. Despite the oversimplification of this equation, this approach was useful to describe the overall MDA performances quantitatively because MDA is recognized as a first-order reaction [119,158]. For fitting, we used the BT yield (Y) instead of the CH4 conversion because the BT molecules were the desired products, and the deactivation of the BAS (i.e., active sites for aromatization) occurred before the deactivation of the Mo species (i.e., active sites for dehydrogenation) during the entire course of MDA, as established in this section. The parameters k and a were extracted by fitting the experimental BT yields from a TOS of ca. 4.5-12.4 h because the calculated R 2 values were close to unity in that range (Fig. 9(a) and Table 2 ). Initially, the fitted values for k (i.e., rate constant) were expected to decrease monotonically in the following order: Mo/M_400 > Mo/M ~ Mo/M_500 > Mo/M_600, with respect to BT yields (Fig. 9(a)). However, the resulting values were on a similar order of magnitude (5.9-8.1 × 10−3 ) and could be regarded as statistically indistinguishable because of their uncertainty reflected by the confidence intervals (Table 2). Considering the complexity of the four catalysts, apparently owing to distinct amounts of BAS and Mo distributions (as is the case with Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600) [159], these comparable values based on the simplified model in Eq. (1) likely resulted from the non-pronounced difference in BT yields. Nevertheless, all four catalysts showed significantly different deactivation behaviors, allowing us to focus on parameter a (i.e., the deactivation coefficient, which can represent the number of active sites: BAS). These values decreased in the following order: Mo/M_600 > Mo/M_500 > Mo/M > Mo/M_400. This indicated that Mo/M_400 was the most stable of the four catalysts, as inferred from the performance shown in Fig. 5(a). In particular, the deactivation coefficients of all four catalysts, when plotted against the total amounts of BT produced during the reaction (i.e., up to ca. 32 h), showed an inverse relationship with the catalytic performance (Fig. 9(b)). With regard to the effects of HT on the performance of Mo-based H-MCM-22 catalysts, the stability of a catalyst could be determined not only by the catalyst’s ability (mainly related to BAS, whose appropriate amount/strength was key to maximizing the formation of intermediate aromatics) to inhibit the pathway to coke formation, but also by the distribution of active Mo species (which should be located within the pores, as clearly observed from low-performing Mo/M_500 or Mo/M_600) within the shape-selective zeolite pores. Scheme 2 shows the apparent outcomes of C2, aromatic (BT and naphthalene), and coke formation with respect to the Mo-impregnated catalyst used for the reaction. We have thoroughly shown the effects of HT on the amount of BAS and, consequently, the Mo distribution. Of the four representative catalysts, Mo/M_400, which had slightly fewer or weaker BAS facilitating coke formation with respect to Mo/M, achieved the longest C2 lifetime and the highest aromatic yields because of the decreased amounts of coke in the aromatic-selective 10-MR pores and the ability of the 12-MR pores to contain coke deposits at a longer reaction time. In this regard, we would like to emphasize that, in addition to the effects of HT on the aromatic and coke formation behaviors, the improved C2 formation lifetime for Mo/M_400 is a notable finding. To the best of our knowledge, this phenomenon has not been previously reported in the literature, including our earlier work [52]. This catalytic performance was followed by that of Mo/M, which contained an excess amount of such coke-promoting BAS, possibly present within its 10- and 12-MR pores. Finally, although Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600 had higher 12-MR pore volumes than Mo/M throughout the MDA reaction for up to ca. 32 h (Fig. S20), the severe dealumination of their H-MCM-22 supports, which favored the anchoring of Mo species outside instead of inside, prevented further enhancement of catalytic performance. 3.4 Comparison of the MDA catalytic performance of pristine and dealuminated H-MCM-22-supported Mo catalysts with those of Mo-impregnated MCM-22 or ZSM-5 catalysts reported in the literature Fig. 10 shows an overview of the MDA catalytic performance of previously reported Mo-impregnated MCM-22 and ZSM-5 catalysts [51,74,76,77,85,107,118,122,128,160–170]. For fair comparison, the MDA performance of catalysts after a TOS of ca. 6-7 h, lying well within the TOS of interest (ca. 4.5-8.1 h, as addressed in Section 3.2), was considered; unless otherwise noted, the reaction conditions (ca. 700 °C, 1 atm, and 1500–1800 mL·g−1·h−1) were similar to those (ca. 700 °C, 1 atm, and 1500 mL·g−1·h−1) employed in this work. Numbers in parentheses (i.e., (n 1, n 2)) denote the nominal weight percent loading of Mo (n 1) and the Si/Al ratio (n 2) of the zeolite support. In addition, the MDA performance of the Mo-impregnated ZSM-5 catalysts (i.e., Mo/Z (ca. 8.6% CH4 conversion and 65.4% selectivity) and Mo/Z_400 (ca. 8.9% CH4 conversion and 67.9% selectivity)) reported in a previous study [52] are included in Fig. 10. For this study, we prepared and tested the MDA performance of pristine H-MCM-22-supported catalysts (designated by solid black squares) with different Mo loadings (3 and 10 wt% Mo contents) and Si/Al ratios (30 and 50). Most of the previously reported pristine ZSM-5- or MCM-22-supported Mo catalysts (designated by open circles and squares, respectively), which had Si/Al ratios higher than that (ca. 15) of Mo/M (ca. 8.6% CH4 conversion and 75.6% selectivity), displayed lower BT or benzene yields. We noticed that the pristine ZSM-5-supported Mo catalyst (i.e., (10, 15)), reported to have the highest yield (ca. 9.5% CH4 conversion and 81.4% selectivity) [168], had a higher Mo loading (10 wt%) than that (6 wt%) of Mo/M but a Si/Al ratio of 15 comparable to that (15) of Mo/M. However, the H-MCM-22 zeolite support (Si/Al ratio of 15) with 10 wt% Mo-impregnated content (i.e., (10, 15); prepared in this study) showed a very inferior performance (ca. 1.3% CH4 conversion and 3.1% selectivity). Furthermore, ZSM-5-based catalysts having comparable contents/properties (e.g., (10, 15) at a higher space velocity (2400 mL·g−1·h−1) [118] and (9, 11.5) at a similar space velocity (1500 mL·g−1·h−1) [52]) showed very poor performance. In addition, the H-MCM-22-supported Mo catalyst with a lower Mo loading (3 wt%) at the same Si/Al ratio (15) (i.e., (3, 15); prepared in this study) performed worse (ca. 7.1% CH4 conversion and 76.7% selectivity) than that of Mo/M (i.e., (6, 15)). Thus, the optimum MDA catalyst, containing 6 wt% Mo with a nominal Si/Al ratio of 15, was used for the purposes of this study. In addition to the pristine support-based Mo catalysts, we included those that underwent some form of dealumination (accordingly, the amount of BAS decreased) [51,52,74,76,77], designated by colored symbols in Fig. 10. In terms of BT or benzene yields, most dealuminated catalysts showed worse MDA catalytic performances than Mo/M_400 (ca. 9.3% CH4 conversion and 81.2% selectivity). Although a specially treated catalyst showed a similar BT or benzene yield (ca. 12.3% CH4 conversion and 62.5% selectivity, denoted with a dark cyan circle), it is worth noting that our method (as reflected by the remarkable performance of Mo/M_400) involved only a single pretreatment step, in contrast to such catalyst that required careful preparation: (1) the NH4-ZSM-5 support was first calcined in moist air and (2) subsequently calcined in dry N2 [51]. Considering that this catalyst had a higher Si/Al ratio of 25 at the same Mo loading (6 wt%) (i.e., (6, 25)), we prepared and evaluated a pristine catalyst having a comparable Si/Al ratio of 30 (i.e., (6, 30)) but the resulting MDA performance (ca. 5.9% CH4 conversion and 53.8% selectivity) did not show any potential for improvement, which was also the case for a pristine catalyst with a much higher Si/Al ratio of 50 (i.e., (6, 50) with ca. 2.4% CH4 conversion and 38.3% selectivity). Having optimized an MDA catalyst (i.e., Mo/M_400) relative to Mo/M via HT for the primary goal of converting CH4 into value-added aromatic products, its competitive performance can now be further leveraged by process intensification. Indeed, the performance of Mo/M_400 offers a significant head start for future development, particularly in the context of MDA catalysts with hydrothermally dealuminated zeolite supports. To overcome thermodynamic and kinetic barriers related to coke formation and thereby prolong the MDA performance of Mo/M_400, process intensification strategies such as (1) co-feeding with oxidants (e.g., CO2 or steam) [171,172], (2) periodic pulsing with O2 [173], or (3) integrating an O2-permeable membrane reactor [174] can be employed. 4 Conclusions In this study, we investigated the effect of the hydrothermal dealumination of H-MCM-22 supports before impregnation with Mo on the MDA catalytic performance. Thus, we prepared catalysts whose H-MCM-22 supports were dealuminated using steam at different HT temperatures and the physicochemical properties of the corresponding representative catalysts (i.e., Mo/M_x; x = 400, 500, and 600) were investigated. HT did not considerably change the physical (i.e., structural and textural) properties but altered the acidic sites. The MDA performance of the pristine (i.e., Mo/M) and hydrothermally treated H-MCM-22-supported Mo catalysts was analyzed, revealing differences in the BT formation rates in the following order of increasing activity: Mo/M_400 > Mo/M > Mo/M_500 > Mo/M_600. Concomitantly, the lifetime of the C2 formation rates before abrupt decline was the longest for Mo/M_400, which was then followed by Mo/M. In addition, Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600 showed the shortest C2 formation lifetimes before decreasing. Analysis of the fresh Mo-impregnated catalysts via H2-TPR measurements revealed that Mo/M and Mo/M_400 had comparable Mo distributions, but the higher concentrations of external Mo species in Mo/M_500 and Mo/M_600 indicated that the Mo distributions in the latter catalysts negatively affected the overall MDA performance. The deteriorating performance could be attributed to the loss of the framework Al in the zeolite pores after harsh HT (i.e., M_500 and M_600). After comparing the performance of Mo/M_400 relative to Mo/M, it was inferred that the reduction of BAS by dealumination altered their spatial interaction with the active Mo species, which favored aromatic (BT and naphthalene) formation rates. Meanwhile, coke analysis via combined TG and Ar physisorption analyses further clarified the superior performance of Mo/M_400 over Mo/M. In particular, the decreased amounts of coke in the aromatic-selective 10-MR pores, as well as the ability of the 12-MR pores to contain coke deposits at a longer reaction time improved the stability of Mo/M_400. Nevertheless, for all H-MCM-22-supported Mo catalysts, it was apparent that both hard and soft coke caused deactivation, with the soft coke fraction ultimately deactivating the active Mo species. The trends in deactivation of Mo/M and Mo/M_x (x = 400, 500, and 600) were also quantified in terms of the deactivation coefficients (parameter a), and the values were inversely proportional to their cumulative amounts of BT. Finally, the MDA performance of Mo/M_400 was very superior to previously reported ones and competitive with that of a carefully treated Mo-impregnated MCM-22 catalyst reported in the literature. The findings of this work emphasize that the optimal modification of BAS through dealumination boosted both the catalytic activity and stability of Mo/M_400, specifically improving the yields of the desired aromatic products and inhibiting its rapid deactivation. This was primarily due to the reduced BAS in the H-MCM-22 supports while still maintaining proper and effective Mo distribution in the high-performance catalyst. coredata.dc:description: In this study, we investigated Mo-impregnated H-MCM-22 catalysts (denoted Mo/M) for methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) to produce aromatics such as benzene and toluene (BT). We attempted to improve the performance of the MDA catalysts by reducing the amount of Brönsted acid sites (BAS) of the H-MCM-22 supports via hydrothermal dealumination. Among the prepared catalysts, an optimal hydrothermal treatment (HT) of H-MCM-22 supports at 400 °C, followed by Mo impregnation (denoted Mo/M_400), resulted in a reduced and optimal amount of BAS, along with a comparable Mo distribution to Mo/M. Further, Mo/M_400 enhanced BT formation rates (maximum BT formation rate of 5.23 vs. 4.73 mmolBT·g−1·h−1 for Mo/M); it appears that dealumination-induced reduction in the quantity of BAS altered their spatial interaction with active Mo species, promoting BT and naphthalene formation. Interestingly, the lifetime of intermediate C2 (ethane and ethylene) formation was also improved for Mo/M_400. Rigorous coke analyses revealed that the decreased coke content in the aromatic-selective 10-membered-ring (10-MR) pores, as well as the ability of the 12-MR pores to accommodate coke deposits over a longer reaction time, improved the stability of Mo/M_400. Nonetheless, for all catalysts, the deactivations of BAS, and subsequently, the active Mo sites were mainly ascribed to coke deposition. The overall enhancement in MDA performance by Mo/M_400 was attributed to the advantages of the optimally reduced BAS, allowing such performance to surpass those of previously reported Mo-based catalysts.

coredata.dc:title: Simple removal of framework aluminum from MWW type zeolites for unprecedented optimal Mo-impregnated catalysts: Systematic elucidation of coke deposition and its impact on methane dehydroaromatization
